Article.Title: A Moment of Inspiration
Article.ByLine: an avatar for me in my happy place
Article.Summary: Labor Day Sunday. All is well. Trying to feel happy. In the background Media Play in loading information. One of things that came up was an idea to have pictures of book covers link to my books. I was thinking Then, out of the blue came an email from OneDrive and I don't know how, of the perfect cover for The Blond Jew.
Article.Contents:
There are still plenty of things to do on this website.

  • redo the home page after all these years
  • remove the border from this editor
  • build a collapsible chapter list
  • design distinctive backgrounds for each of the category filter pages.
  • add a meta tag builder and maybe perma-link pages for search engine optimization
  • add a tag system
  • add login functionality (use micro services?)
  • work on my Professional page
  • add my resume both clean and real
  • add articles about how I built this website
  • write some technical articles
  • collect a list of resume requirements
  • move saved message down closer to the buttons
  • add a non sync spinner. Find ways to auto save a-sync
  • build a page metaphor page as I once called it
  • I need a project task tool

That's enough for now. What to do first?

Article.Title: We're Probably Living in a Simulation
Article.ByLine: By Mike Wall, Space.com Senior Writer
Article.Summary: In my science philosophy book which I might name Time Squared and still needs a good book cover. I guess any Hubble galaxy picture will do. My other book Ready Aim Fire also needs a good book cover. Musk is a character deserving of more attention.
Article.Contents:
I want to add a tool bar to embed this youtube video. Just another thing I want to do

I can paste a link to this article. Maybe that's enough. I can cut and paste parts of other web pages.



<div style="position:relative;height:0;padding-bottom:61.73%"><iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ycPr5-27vSI?ecver=2" style="position:absolute;width:100%;height:100%;left:0" width="583" height="360" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe></div>


The universe is 13.8 billion years old, so any civilizations that may have arisen throughout the cosmos have had loads and loads of time to hone their technological know-how, the SpaceX founder and CEO explained early this morning (Sept. 7) during a long, wide-ranging and very entertaining appearance on comedian Joe Rogan's popular podcast, "


The Joe Rogan Experience."



"If you assume any rate of improvement at all, then games will be indistinguishable from reality, or civilization will end. One of those two things will occur," Musk said. "Therefore, we are most likely in a simulation, because we exist."




"Why would you make a simulation that's boring? You'd make a simulation that's way more interesting than base reality," Musk said, citing the video games and movies that humanity makes, which are "distillation[s] of what's interesting about life."


The billionaire entrepreneur is far from alone in this interpretation; a number of physicists, cosmologists and philosophers find the simulation hypothesis compelling. If even one advanced alien civilization with a predilection for creating simulations has ever arisen out there, the reasoning goes, then it could theoretically pop off thousands — or perhaps even millions or billions — of "fake" universes. And it would be hard for the inhabitants of these digital realms to figure out the truth, because all the evidence they could gather would likely be planted by the creators. 


Indeed, the simulation idea is one of many possible explanations for the famous Fermi paradox, which basically asks, "Where is everybody?" ("Everybody" being aliens, of course.)


This was far from the only ground that Musk and Rogan covered during their 2.5-hour conversation. For example, Musk reiterated his concerns about unregulated and uncontrolled artificial intelligence; stressed that a bright and appealing future for humanity involves exploring and settling other worlds, both in our solar system and beyond; and discussed the traffic-reducing potential of extensive tunnel systems, which his Boring Company aims to build in big cities around the world.


Musk also talked at length about Tesla, the electric-car company he runs, and the need for our species to wean itself off fossil fuels. Musk described humanity's mass displacement of carbon from the ground to the atmosphere (and from there into the oceans) as an incredibly dangerous experiment whose ultimate outcome is unknown.



"We should not do this," he told Rogan. "We know that sustainable energy is the end point. So why are we doing this experiment? It's an insane experiment. It's the dumbest experiment in human history." [Images of Melt: Earth's Vanishing Ice]


Musk also casually mentioned that he has an idea for an electric supersonic plane that takes off and lands vertically. But he said he doesn't view the development of this concept as a priority at the moment, given the other pressing problems humanity needs to solve.


Musk and Rogan sipped whiskey throughout their conversation. And at one point, the comedian lit up a joint, and Musk took a puff.


This was apparently a rare event; the SpaceX CEO said he almost never smokes marijuana (which is legal in California, where The Joe Rogan Experience is taped) and doesn't enjoy it, because it saps his famous productivity.


"It's like a cup of coffee in reverse," Musk said. "I like to get things done. I like to be useful." 


He told Rogan that ideas are bouncing around inside his head all the time — "it's like a never-ending explosion" — and that he realized he was different from other people when he was just 5 or 6 years old.


"I thought I was insane," Musk said. As a kid, he added, he worried that authority figures might notice his "strangeness" and put him away somewhere.




There was so much other interesting stuff as well. For example, Musk appreciatively handled a samurai sword in the studio that Rogan said was 500 years old. And at one point toward the end of the conversation, Musk said, "This may sound corny, but love is the answer." (Another choice quote: "I don't know what would happen if I got in a sensory-deprivation tank. Sounds concerning.")

You can watch the entire thing on The Joe Rogan Experience's YouTube page. 

Follow Mike Wall on Twitter @michaeldwall and Google+. Follow us @Spacedotcom, Facebook or Google+. Originally published on Space.com.

Article.Title: I Am What I Am
Article.Summary:
Moving along nicely even though time is going by fast. I Went down to my local server for a while and may have to go back to that local xml file because i had some good inspiration there.
What the hell just happened? I just lost some work
Article.Contents:
Currently experiencing a warm prolonged spell of absolute joy. Can't remember anything like this.

All the weight of all the bad decisions and regret\able


I do everything except actually use this thing. OK I fixed the time. Now what?

  • I got the date display and the date sort order working, 
  • I put the service location in the web config.
  • Now maybe I don't need to add date edit to this page. But since I put stuff in from long ago I could use it.
  • Still need to put categories in a table
  • add a Hit counter
  • add an admin form to update categories
  • it's time to put the carousel back
  • pages for all footer links






On any page, you can right click and choose Inspect Element in ParseHub to view the HTML layout of the page. This is important to do, so that we can design XPath to pick out the element we want.

Right clicking on the particular element, if you can find it, and inspecting that element will take you to its tag's location in the HTML.

If you hover over tags in the HTML view, the page will highlight the element that your cursor is hovering over.

Article.Title: Post Biological
Article.Summary: Watching Ancient Aliens. The graphics are astounding. Amazing. Now they are talking about self replicating machines i.e 3D printers Susan Schneider what a beautiful scientist. There has to be better ways to seed my home page. Who am I doing all this for? After worrying about threat artificial intelligence the show ends with a fatalistic predestination predetermination theory that we were always meant to create self replicating machines and that we ourselves already are self replicating machines. Lets digitize our consciousness and shoot it out across the the universe.
Article.Contents:
Sitting with my old wife coming to grips with all the fantastic technology already available in our world. There's so much available on the internet and the digital streaming services. Maybe what we are creating now already existed long ago. But why do we have to get old and die?

Maybe so we don't get obsolete. Remember renting videos at blockbuster? We spend so much of our lives worrying about things that don't end up gathering dust on the shelf mattering little.

Compared to other planets at least in our solar system Earth is so beautiful. these are indeed random thoughts. That's what you get when you try to write while watching TV. Even so; using this wonderful tool I have built brings me great joy.

Only humans remain when once there were several other primate species intelligent hominids but we sapiens killed them all off. We were the most violent

Rapallo Italy immortal jellyfish reverts to its original pollup state and recycles itself over and over. I love watching Ancient Aliens. Cosmic seeds panspermia.

Phrase it in fatalistic terms: Maybe aliens put all sorts of different life forms

Super Powers

Antthing you can think of you can bring into being. That's the good news and also the bad news.

PUT search terms you would like to master in meta tags.

animal grade: multi-cellular

so many topics worthy of a meta tag. search terms worthy of an image search.

I need a tag for private conversations. or at least cut these random notes out and put them somewhere else. Right now I can use this tool for entirely private play because no one else cares. The aliens that supposedly crashed both in Russia and Roswell


Oh I want to jump up and work some more on this app but I'm staying here with my wife watching TV

Photo Albums. another feature I'd like to add to my web site are my photo collections. Just like OggleBooble. But all that matters is original material. who needs more presentation of other people's material.


Were other worldly forces

Tsiolkovsky father of modern rocket science.

cosmoism the call of the cosmos.

Damn I wish I could get the website icon to work

light beings

synthetic beings

places where such things as human discetion are allowed some technologies can advance further

EVERYTHING SHOULD BE WRITTEN AS DIALOG

different avatar personalities need to be invented

Article.Title: Latest Changes to This Web Site
Article.Summary: I can't help it, I'm very happy with all that I've accomplished on this project. I took my pretty table of contents formatting and automated it. Now the chapters, sections and subsections come from the xml file. It's time to take a break. Do a little gardening, mow the yard. The yard looks terrible but it's been too hot. Damn, I had a idea and now I can't remember it.
Article.Contents:
There's still lots of little things needed to be done, and some big ones.

  • set different backgrounds on the article jogs based on category
  • ADD the ability to view the real document
  • add hit counter - DONE but this one was way too hard. I had all sorts of trouble getting this one to work. I'm been able to get a web API call I just couldn't get a web api post to work from c# code. I need to write an article about this, a professional article to put out at the right place on my site.
  • add meta tag builder this could be my next big project. $(header).append. So on this page I need a list box control of some kind. A pick or add tool.
  • my library. I wonder if I can get a book scanner.
  • I need to practice printing.
  • Ctrl-S
  • my To Do tool will have a prior-need, prerequisite feature and a sub-task feature.
  • need to do an article on Stephen Miller.
  • a madisonian nightmare - the theme of Philo the tragedy of the Jewish messiah shown as a parallel to republicanism
  • another political rant about ideological extremists -- it's all about Jesus
  • great power zero responsibility How Sean Hannity rules the United States
  • I don't call it America
  • terra incognito exceptionalism- how half the planet got its name the US isn't even the largest nation of the Americas
  • my imaginary confessions of Paul Manafort
  • the little river band

Seems the save feature on the view button only kicks in after an initial update has occurred. That's similar to another error I am still having. There has to be more than one section under a chapter for the menu to work correctly. Now that is a strange one.


As I wrote a minute ago but lost is there's always lots of idea of things I can do and add, but sometimes it's time to stop and force yourself to do some planning.

As I will write in my book Ready Fire Aim that my problem is that ideas sometimes form whole in my mind and I'm ready and completely able to jump right into coding.

When an idea comes to me boom I'm ready to hit it. BUT when I get into it I quickly get into problems.


The ultimate bigotry of lowering soft expectations

You are what you do.



But the problem is some thing which I need to come up with a name for which will be the basis of my ToDo list is that there is often Things That Need To Be Done Before You Can Do It. That's obviously too long a name for the concept I want to patent.

Article.Title: Candidates Matter
Article.Summary: I live in Texas. For the first time my vote really matters. If Beto wins that would be a gain of one for the D's and a loss of one for the R's. That's a flip of two seats. And it's not just that Beto has different political views than his opponent. Beto is a compelling charismatic personality. It really makes a difference if a political candidate has IT. It's hard to say what IT is but you know it when you see it. He's handsome and articulate and passionate. Passion you can feel. And then there's Alexandria.
Article.Contents:
In polarized America it's fair to say that all that matters is the color of your team jersey. There has always been a hill outside of town where unwanted, rejected, deformed or socially inexpedient little bundles were left for the wolves. Anyway, I'll talk about abortion later. As I was saying, this Kavanaugh appointment, as all republicans desperate for an excuse for Trump freely claim, they value conservative judges and justices for all sorts of reasons. Anyway, I'll talk about republican hypocrisy later. But one example of conservative willingness to overlook anything in pursuit of "getting over" on the liberals is the tolerance judge Kavanaugh's character. The guy is as big a scumbag as Trump. Except, this one will be with us for a generation.

Article.Title: Passion Wins Over Reason
Article.Summary: Of all the criminal acts performed by Paul Manafort perhaps the most disastrous and long lasting damage is what he has done to our Constitution. To appreciate the magnitude of the affront we have go back and look at some of the history. And we have to appreciate the word democracy and understand the difference between a Republic and a Democracy. Everyone call the USA a democracy, but if you remember the Pledge of Allegiance from elementary school it's "to the Republic for which it stands". We are supposedly a Republic. What does that mean?
Article.Contents:
What's the difference between a democracy and a republic? And what's the big deal?

Technically, a democracy is when laws are made and decisions are made by direct popular vote, and a republic employs something called representative government. In anything other a small tribe or village, getting everyone to vote on every issue becomes impractical. So the concept of a quorum was devised. An appropriate percentage of citizens can be a representative sample of the popular vote. Eventually you arrive at representative government.

It's a matter of certain knowledge that democracy is the greatest, most wonderful perfect ideal in the history of the world. Republics have all sorts of problems. The elite or other special interests tend to take over control. However, democracies have a few problems too. Our Founding Fathers deliberately created a very specific and rather elaborate form of government which it called a Republic. James Madison's biggest complaint with democracy had to do with his opinion of common people.




Bud Lite For The Many Not The Few.


But, a republic implies other features. Plato wrote a book considering the ins and outs.


a quorum of all citizens, and a republic means representative government; government by a quorum elected representatives. What's the big deal? What's the distinction and what's the big deal. It comes down to a fundamental position. Do you consider human beings fundamentally good or fundamentally evil?

Actually, it's more insidious than that, especially in this politically correct age of #me too. It's also problematic in light of the "All Men Are Created Equal" statement that young Thomas screed in his Declaration of Independence. Yes, under the law, in the eyes of law all people are should be considered equal, every man women and child.


But, in reality no two people are created equal, with the possible exception of identical twins raised together.

Not only are no two people

Tags.Tag: passion never fails to wrest the sceptre from reason
to the republic for which it stands

“He believed that suckers stay out of debt,” the colleague told me. His unrestrained spending and pile of debt required a perpetual search for bigger paydays and riskier ventures.


I apologize to my son and my brother but I am no longer interested in tolerating, trying to accept or even bother to understand Trump conservatives.



An article in the Atlantic makes the argument that the most terrible thing Manafort is responsible for is the bringing the practices of of corrupt countries. That's a nice racist east coast elitist Atlantic Monthly


So much about America’s view of itself resists accepting a disturbing reality. Conventional wisdom long held that America’s free market would never tolerate the sort of clientelism, nepotism, and outright theft that prevailed in places like Brazil and Italy. Americans thought that globalization would export the hygienic habits of this nation’s financial system and its values of good government to the rest of the world. But over the past three decades, the opposite transpired: America has become the sanctuary of choice for laundered money, a bastion of shell companies and anonymously purchased real estate. Article.Title: True To Form
Article.Summary: No one's opinion changed. Whether one uses the spinal cord fear based brain or the rational cognitive lobes will not change over the course of this one debate. The deep red non-thinking majority registered with neural blasts of ecstatic joy when Cruz blasted illegal immigrants, and genuflected to guns and god. Cruz knows the formula. Beto applied reason with his own brand of passion and sincerity. Beto was nervous but remained articulate. Who won depends on what one wants to hear which depends on where one stands on the issues.
Article.Contents:
My favorite line delivered in tonight's debate between Beto O'Rourke / Ted Cruz debate came after the slimy lawyer Ted gave a long winded left handed seeming complement.

Beto just rolled his eyes and said. "True to form". There was a spontaneous explosion of applause. Some people got it. Kind of an inside joke.

You have to know to that which he was referring. You have to appreciate scumbag Ted's well known modus operandi So, after Cruz got done with a rambling hate drenched supposed compliment, an old saw; "My opponent is sincere in his beliefs, his radical anti American, out of the main stream ideas." Beto slipped in a three word reply.  

True to form.

Bret Stephens in the New York Times on Ted Cruz: He's like a serpent covered in Vaseline. He treats the American people like two-bit suckers in 10 gallon hats. He sucks up to guy who insulted his wife by reteet, no less. Phony piety an even phonier principles. I see him as a cross between Jimmy Swaggart and the shining His ethics are purely situational he makes Trump look like a human being by comparison. Cruz is conniving enough to put one over on you but not perceptive enough to know that you see right through him. He's the type of man who would sell his family into slavery to win an election and then bemoan their slavery as a sob story to get himself reelected.

Given that visually and physically Cruz exudes such a disgusting demeanor, what explains hi success? How could such a sleazebag get elected to the senate and almost made it to the presidency. The explanation is that he happens to be a very skilled rhetorician. Whenever someone who speaks well waxes eloquent conservative spinal cord, wave the flag, racist xenophobic hot buttons you have to wonder about sincerity. Could Ted Cruz be a sophist?


Rhetoric

the word rhetoric has been given a bad name. Fancy evasive empty talk is dismissed as labeling it rhetoric. Most people today would define rhetoric as "empty meaningless talk". Actually, empty talk is the opposite of rhetoric, or at least not very good rhetoric. Because the traditional definition of the word rhetoric is closer to "The Art of Persuasion" Selling an insurance policy is persuasion, asking someone out on a date, taking a job interview, getting elected to office is the art of persuasion and an exercise is rhetoric. Advocating for your position online, in a business conference room or on the floor of the general assembly the art of persuasion is rhetoric.

Aristotle wrote a book about it as have many others. Debate clubs practice the art. Appeals to reason and appeals to ethics are considered but all agree logic and morals are never more effective than plays to emotion.

Recognizing the massive importance of rhetoric in so much of human activity from making a deal to getting a job to convincing your friends which restarunt to go for dinner, I'm sorry to report there may be a dark side to the ancient and respected art of rhetoric.

There's a small problem. Sophisticated practitioners have discovered effective ways to manipulate people by inflaming their emotions. Masters of the art of persuasion have a tremendous power.

Sleazy Ted is good at his own form of ridicule and fear mongering, racially coded, hate drenched word craft that qualifies as rhetoric.




One of the most existentially lasting horrors that will outlast all the sliminess of Ted Cruz is the complete misrepresentation of 2nd amendment, codifying the individual's right to bear arms, which simply not what the Constitution state. Ted argued the Heller case.

Article.Title: Karma
Article.Summary: Some believe Karma can exist in this world. What goes around comes around. Others, like myself, have no faith the justice exists. Only the good die young. Most fortunes are stolen or come about in unjust ways that advantage a very few at the expense of the masses. The world is not fair. There is no justice. So it's perfect that an elite elitist partisan culture warrior should be given the title Supreme Court Justice. Justice Kavanaugh
Article.Contents:
But for those aficionados of karma, these sexual assault hearings indeed bring back around on the instigator what he himself once visited upon another. Along with Ken Starr it was this guy Brent who deliberately set out to torture and humiliate Bill Clinton with the Monica Lewinski deposition and subsequent impeachment. Brent was the one advocating that they relentlessly pursue the most embarrassing and indelicate questions possible in order to inflict as much political damage as possible.

That which you imagine in your mind is that which comes into actual material existence. That is why one's worst fears are so often realized. By mentally constructing in your imagination that which you most worry about you give reality the material to create it.

As a privileged high school stud Bret was able to actualize fantasies unavailable to many subscribers to Playboy magazine. Then as a partisan warrior former Young Republican finding himself plotting the destruction of Bill Clinton you have to wonder if he ever thought in the back of his mind "I just hope none of the stuff I did ever gets found out." Maybe he obsessively thought out the details. Now, exactly as he imagined, he worst fears are being realized.

Article.Title: Dynamically Create Local Databases
Article.Summary: Say you have a web site for Masonic lodges that offers to track members and meetings, yearly officer chairs and so on. Or, maybe you have a job search app that keeps track of where you send resumes and contacts and phone calls and interviews. Every user wants their data protected and kept away from other users. Believe it or not I originally did it using xml files. But a database is more appropriate. My service provider plan only allows me one SQL database but I had the idea to use SQL Express local .mdb files.
Article.Contents:
I got it to work, but it turns out you need to have SQL Express on the hosting service which my provider GoDaddy, doesn't offer. So here's how I did it anyway.

Entity Framework has a feature called .CreateIfNotExists, but it normally applies to a specific model with it's tables all defined. I don't want to create an entire new model class and all the table models for every new client database, so what I did was create one sample model called Master, and use it as a reference when creating queries and procs, but create a separate dbContent object.


The Trick


When I built the EF model I chose Create New Connection.

Article.Title: Absolutivity
Article.Summary: Relativity is just that; the perspective from a relative position. The theory of Relativity explains nicely how things appear from where we are here and now. And where are we? We are under several layers of atmosphere, inside an electromagnetic field pulsing from the poles, on the surface of a sphere rotating at about one thousand miles per hour, revolving around a star 93 million miles away 67,108 miles per hour. The star we call the sun is itself travels at almost half a million miles per hour within the Milky Way Galaxy.
Article.Contents:
I don't believe in Einstein's theory of Relativity by the way. I think it's stupid. It makes no sense. It appears that time and motion have some

sort of affect on each other, but that's all it is, appearance, a perception. Just because the police car siren seems to make a strange whooping

sound as it passes by your particular location is only a commentary on your individual perception, not the inherent nature of the police siren




itself. What arrogance! What a perfect commentary on the selfish, egotistical nature of man that we can base our entire physical theory of the

nature of the universe on a subjective, individualistic parlor trick.

The notion that you're going to live longer, by millions of centuries if you sit inside a spacecraft traveling faster than the speed of light,

not only is stupid, it makes no sense. First of all, it is highly unlikely that three dimensional physical matter existing in sequential space

time, which is what we are, can travel anywhere close to the speed of light. If we did we might cease to exist as matter and become something

more like pure energy, which is great, but for us, existing as physical matter, preferably with large sex organs, is what it's all about.


But if you could travel at hundreds of times the speed of light, and it took you five earth years to go somewhere cool, and then five Earth

years to get back, but you and the people you left behind would all be ten years older next Thanksgiving. And ten years closer to death I might

add. Why, because in the preceding sentence I just said Earth years. And throughout the whole sentence you remained an Earth like, air breathing,

urine evacuating human being. And traveling in a plane relatively faster than somebody else has nothing to do with anything.


Einstein, Time Magazine's Man of the Millennium, was an idiot. He had one "spaced out" theory in his youth that "appears" to be observable. He

then proceeded to spend the rest of his life failing to come up with an explanation that could tie As Above with So Below, the quantum with the

cosmic, even though the ancients had already apparently managed to do so


I don't believe in Relativity, but then again I don't believe in gravity.





﻿

Article.Title: As Above So Below
Article.Summary: This is some leftover stuff from many years ago. This really belongs somewhere else like in my book Time Squared
Article.Contents:
As Above So Below. This is the motto of the most ancient school of wisdom from the earliest lost reaches. This one phrase is essentially all we have left from a race

that came before perhaps fifty thousand or seven hundred thousand years ago. 

What does it mean?

Here's what it means to me.

Imagine if the most profound bit of wisdom to arise so far in this cycle is to be found in the a skit in the movie 
Animal House where the freshman was smoking pot with his professor.


Larry: [to Jennings, while high] Okay. That means that our whole solar system could be, like one tiny atom in the fingernail of some other giant being. [Jennings nods] This is too much! That means one tiny atom in my fingernail could be--

Jennings: Could be one little tiny universe.

Larry: Could I buy some pot from you?



The idea is universally pooh-poohed, laughed off as the classic example   of marijuana induced deep insight, where you are convinced you have
just discovered the greatest theoretical breakthrough since 
relativity only to realize, after you sober up, that you have uncovered 
only a most duh inducing obvious, if not outright stupid statement. 


Except that this one has stuck with me for a long time, and the more I learn, and the more human knowledge advances, the more reasonable
this idea seems.


Consider infinity. Ha Ha, It's
to really even begin to contemplate the word. Infinity and Eternity.  Imagine the biggest thing possible, for example a giant organism
of which the entire solar system is but one part of a cell wall under its fingernail. Now double that, and double it again forever. 
The organism in which we are but an atom floating around in its pancreas is itself but sitting on a planet which is but an electron 
spinning around in an atom that is but a part of the cell wall of some even larger (much larger) organism. And 
next to us is another hair folicle of a universe much like our own.

impossible to do what I just asked. I'm serious. It is literally physically impossible

Article.Title: The Emerald Tablet
Article.Summary: Possibly the oldest document in the world, the mineral, emerald, on which it is written is impossible to date. For those who suspect that there may have been antediluvian civilizations more advanced intellectually and perhaps even technologically than we have today. Antediluvian is a biblical term which means "before the flood". A story similar to Noah's, where the world is destroyed by a great flood, appears in hundreds of ancient cultures. Many agree that it may be a reference to the melting of glaciers that covered the earth as recently as 10,000 years ago. Ten thousand years is less that a blink in terms of geologic time. Bi-pedal hominid bones and even footprints have been found that are a million or two or three years old. What could have happened fifty thousand or two hundred thousand years ago? That would still leave two million nine hundred and eighty thousand years still unaccounted for."That which is below is like that which is on high. and that which is on high is like that which is below; by these things are made the miracles of one thing." Was this passed down to us from the eons? Why? And what could it mean?
Article.Contents:
The legend of Thrice Great Hermes Trismegistus, a Greek translation of the Egyptian god of Knowledge Troth, has suffered from the slight detail that essentiallyall of the potentially greatest store of wisdom ever has been lost. Throughout the dark ages, and up until recent times, lots of bogus alchemy and witchcraft, and all manner of weird and crazy stuff has been passed off as "Hermetic Writings".

Although it may be dozens of hundreds of years old in some cases, it none the less remains thousands of years more recent than any actual ancient wisdom, if indeed there ever was any, except for one tiny scrap The Emerald Tablet seems to have survived, even though it too seems now lost to the public The Emerald Tablet the Tabula Smaragdina, may have survived longer than most all else precisely because it seems it was quite literally carved in stone, on a slab of green desert glass. There is no way to date an inorganic slab of a mineral. it could be very, very old. Most of it is fairly boring animistic esoteric, cosmic comments, which have been expanded on by many. But there is one phrase from the ancient past that fascinates me the most. There are many translations. T


hat which is below is like that which is on high. and that which is on high is like that which is below; by these things are made the miracles of one thing

1) It is true without untruth, certain and most true
2) that which is below is like that which is on high, and that which is on high is like that which is below; by these things are made the miracles of one thing.
3) And as all things are, and come from One, by the mediation of One, So all things are born from this unique thing by adaption.
4) The Sun is the father and the Moon the mother.
5) The wind carries it in its stomach. The earth is its nourisher and its receptacle.
6 The Father of all t0he Theleme of the universal world is here.
6a) Its force, or power, remains entire,
7) if it is converted into earth.
7a) You separate the earth from the fire, the subtle from the gross, gently with great industry.
8) It climbs from the earth and descends from the sky, and receives the force of things superior and things inferior.
9) You will have by this way, the glory of the world and all obscurity will flee from you. 1
0) It is the power strong with all power, for it will defeat every subtle thing and penetrate every solid thing
11a) In this way the world was created.
12) From it are born wonderful adaptations, of which the way here is given.
13) That is why I have been called Hermes Tristmegistus, having the three parts of the universal philosophy.
14) This, that I have called the solar Work, is complete


Above So Below. By these things all are made one. Many people might focus on this second observation, that there is a oneness beneath all the strife and diversity and difference and uniqueness of physical life here on Earth, and this is a worthy avenue of philosophical investigation, one that especially benefits from the application of mind altering drugs, I might add. However, it is the often overlooked first statement, Above So Below that most intrigues me, because it supports my Animal House Theory of the Cosmos, that our Solar System is but an atom, our universe but a molecule, and that we exist within the small intestines of some vast organism to which a million years is but a fraction of a second, and under our fingernails exist untold tropical oceans.
I'm talking about the fractal universe. I'm talking about vibrations. The disturbances, the vibrations that cause the electrons to spin, the photon waves traveling through your consciousness. Atoms are solar systems. The universe is an organism, a fibrous jellyfish floating in a comic ocean. Within a single cell of a leaf on a tree with ten billion extremely similar cells on a tree with millions of similar leaves in a field with thousands of other similar trees. Each cell full of billions of atoms. Each atom containing furiously spinning, rotating and orbiting and racing along.
Maybe they knew. Back, ages ago, what did As Above So Below mean to those in the ancients? Could they have some conception of their reality that we today refuse to recognize?
Some speculate that people were more spiritual, more tuned in to the pulses of the Milky Way, more susceptible to the mystical cosmic energy surrounding us than those of us in the practical competitive fast passed material world we live in today. We can't even see the stars at night because of all the artificial ambient light of our electrified computerized, fossil fuel powered twenty four hour drive through flood lit thundering highway existence. Someday after I'm gone somebody may come back and read these words and shake their head at the ignorance of our vicious conservative eco destructive selfish arrogant times and smile that at least I was aware of the infinity in both directions represented by the words As Above So Below. Unlikely that any of this will exist after even a short power outage but you never know.

Article.Title: Reap the Whirlwind
Article.Summary: A cartoon joke president now has an absurd joke supreme court justice. ALL CAPS Hannity now runs the country. Hannity coached Brent how to yell. Thinking people laughed, mocked, did spit takes, marveled. Beyond absurd. You can't make anything up as absurd as the idea of putting anyone with the temperament more completely and perfectly the absolute opposite of the character Hannity convinced his fellow Irish Catholic to portray at his hearing. But it worked. The appointment only proves that screaming with rage about the Clintons still ignights a large enough portion of the electorate. Brent yelled that he takes any attacks on him as personal and that we would all soon reap the whirlwind. But who will reap this whirlwind.
Article.Contents:
Reaping the Whirlwind Turtles all the way down. The Wheels of War are turning. Trying to write while watching TV provides too many distractions to produce much in the way of coherent thought. There's not much to say about the now Justice Brent's record on the court. there is

All I have left is actually use this thing. My computer is in the shop. Everything was taking so long my computer was getting so wrapped up in knots. Sometimes to make one little change move one little I press F5 time after time. Soon the machine entirely locks up.

Once, when I used to go to computer developer meeting groups, the great Scott Hanselman was giving the talk. He had just purchased a solid state hard drive. They were brand new back then and very expensive. Scott waxed poetic about the warm feeling of wellbeing and contentment that has overcome him from his new purchase. He loved how his box boots up super fast, "in a flash" if you'll forgive the pun. (A SSD solid state drive is essentially a large flash drive. Add supposedly apps run many time faster. Since then I have totally wanted a solid state hard drive.

Now, a few years after hearing Scott Hanselman the prices for SSDs have dropped and their size has grown tremendously. Online I found them for around one hundred bucks. Best Buy even had one on special and in stock and within a mile of my house. But it's not enough just to buy this now very small component. You have to install it. And I also want to format it as my boot drive and install my operating system and change my current from a boot drive to a data drive.

Theoretically I could do all that myself. Back in the day I'd jump into a project like that without thinking. After all I'm a computer guy, right? But at my age I understand that driving a car, or even being a professional car driver is not the same as replacing the car's transmission. There is no telling how many things could go wrong

This "unterminated string error' exemplifies the kind of bug that costs hours and days of unnecessarily wasteful and unbearably annoying time.
Article.Contents: Brent has been a partisan warrior for many years. I'm not so worried about abortion. The federal government, the congress, will never pass anti abortion laws. It's not a winning issue; a solid majority of people in most states are opposed to overturning a woman's right to choose. A few states will rush to pass even more elaborate restrictions and they will now make it through any court challenges, but many states will not. Abortion is all about Jesus furor There are many other issues that differentiate liberals from conservatives. Guns; we already live in a world with near maximalist gun rights. Article.Title: BYC Because You Can
Article.Summary: I just removed something that I thought I was very proud of. I wanted to create an image controller on my WebApi service for many years and when I finally got everything working it wasn't that bad. But, what I was doing was passing the image down as a byte array. I got it to show up on my web pages, but when you look at the source code there's a thousands characters long svg encoded or something encoded string. Turns out all I had to do was use the proper service name path.
Article.Contents:
It just goes to show once again that even though you can do something doesn't prove that you should.I just removed something that I thought I was very proud of. I wanted to create an image controller on my WebApi service for many years and when I finally got everything working it wasn't that bad. But, what I was doing was passing the image down as a byte array. I got it to show up on my web pages, but when you look at the source code there's a thousands characters long svg encoded or something encoded string. Turns out all I had to do was use the proper service name path.

now I am working on inserting images in the body here the same way. As this change shows, just getting something to work doesn't mean it can't be improved. Often improvement means simplifying. Occom's Razor states

Right after you get something to work you're pleased and ready to get on to something else. There are always more changes I want to make. I already have a long list.
